title: 'Vulnerable' junior lawyers should be protected by wage award
text:
Solicitors have not traditionally come under an award because their legal training in negotiation and historically high demand for lawyers meant they should be able to advocate for their own work rights.

"But the rationale for excluding junior lawyers from an award just doesn't hold water anymore," said LIV director Brendan Lacota, who worked on the submission.

Low demand

An exponential increase in the number of law graduates meant lawyers "greatly outnumbered available [job] positions", the submission said, diminishing the negotiating power of applicants over pay.

In a single day of admissions sittings in Victoria this August, 240 solicitors were admitted to practice.

Reflecting this, several senior partners last week privately dismissed the effect of the Fair Work changes, predicting no graduate lawyer would complain about unpaid hours because they would be grateful for the job.

Further, the "negotiating skills of early lawyers are underdeveloped" compared to their senior counterparts.

"It should not be assumed that simply because a person is a solicitor that the person is a capable and informed negotiator," the submission said.

Advertisement

"The argument that new lawyers are able to fend for themselves ignores the realities of entry-level legal practice, where entry-level lawyers are simply not equipped or in a bargaining position to argue remuneration and working conditions with partners and human resources staff."

They are also less familiar with their rights and entitlements, it said.

'Significant bullying'

The submission alleged that "significant bullying, discrimination and harassment" in the industry could be damaging the retention of solicitors to both workplaces and the profession.

"This is increasingly important as it relates to more vulnerable new solicitors," it said.

"The expansion of the modern award to create a minimum salary would provide an additional safeguard against discrimination based on gender or other protected personal attributes."

An award for early lawyers would also improve transparency around wages, which was "minimal" for private practice employees, the submission said.

Private legal sector contracts regularly contain gag clauses that prevent employees discussing their wages. While being under an award would not necessarily remove such clauses, Mr Lacota said transparency would still improve as "there'd at least be a publicly available salary floor".

LIV Young Lawyers' push for greater workplace protections follows official complaints about young lawyers' hours at King & Wood Mallesons and Gilbert + Tobin and a rebellion from junior auditors over pay at Deloitte.

Public sector and government lawyers already have wage entitlements that are determined by different negotiating processes, such as enterprise bargaining agreements.
description: A key legal industry body says early-career lawyers were "vulnerable to financial exploitation, mental health crises, wage theft, and [have] reduced negotiating power".
